pros: Work culture is very good.

pros:
Not many pros. 
1. Like other service based companies. 
2. Trying to maintain the name and fame in the market. 
3.This company is good for the trainee level, senior level and Not for mid level who needs to switch in between.
4. Some work life balance is there depending on projects and manager.
cons:
1. Bed compensation and growth. May be there will be no hike at all for two three years, no matter how much you give effort, if your PMR is more than 100%.( It is an rating of the same band in the market assessed.) Based on that you are getting paid and there is less chance of renew or audit of PMR rating. So if you don't know how much ctc you will get according to your Band before joining, and if it is more than the PMR rate you will end up with no hike for next couple of years.

2. You will be entertained or pushed to do some side work, contribution or help in other projects but that will not help or will not be considered in your career progression.  So don't be happy too much.

3. Less chance of getting promotion. You may get lots of appreciation mail doing good but that is the corporate trap to make you feel good which will not help you at all in your career growth.

4. Sometimes company performance which I saw most of the time is below average will impact your appraisal.

5. Managers in IBM is like termite they don't have much context of the project and latest technologies, market standards but still getting huge package. which indirectly blocking the progression of below levels. Don't have proper attigates to behave. Specially at the time of appraisal. 

6. Notice period is 3 months so before joining need to think twice as time of job change it will be a nightmare. As hr will look for the people to join immediately but they will release candidate after serving full notice period.

7. Check for the project details as you may need to work in local client location.

8. Less onsite opportunity. At least less chance within 3 - 4 years.

9.Mails are circulating each and every day regarding the good developments or profits of company which is nothing but illusion. If employees don't have growth at all then top level management is having problem. Because end results is null.

10. No proper coding standards and work methodology maintain.

11 Not good for career building for mid level developer.

pros: IBM has a fantastic ethos of supporting its employees in order to encourage personal and professional growth although promotion system convoluted. It also has a giveback culture through it's social programmes. There is a clear legacy of supporting equality and encouraging diversity. The company fosters a strong sense of pride in its employees in part of the company.
cons: It is a large organisation with a bureaucracy to match. Some processes are slow and others unfathomable. Depending on qualifications and experience there are companies who will pay more; the trade-off is that there is a clear recognition of professional quality attached to being an IBMer. Promotion opportunities exist but you need to be in it for the long haul.

job_title: User Experience Designer in Austin, TX
pros:
I preface this by saying I have a fantastic manager and a very supportive team (IBM Cloud). I'm in the Austin design studio, which if you are in the US is probably where you want to be to get the most out of IBM's design culture. Experiences definitely vary based on your manager & your studio location.

Here are the Pros I can think of:
- I cannot say enough good things about the culture here. People are super smart and are willing to share their knowledge with you. The culture is very collaborative and growth / learning oriented. I see people getting promoted and getting awards regularly and they're not just empty gestures. If you did good, impactful work for IBM, and you have a good manager, then you will likely get some kind of recognition within your team and even across IBM design or your department. It's also a fun culture - e.g. our VP of design did a Tik Tok to promote Think2020 conference; the Austin studio (and other locations too) takes Halloween very seriously with a floor-wide theme, costume contest, and decked-out decorations. e.g. we transformed our space into a Stranger Things mall with food, booze, etc. Halloween is super fun and is really unique to IBM design culture. 

- Feedback is very valued. My team does pulse surveys I think every year or quarter (I forget) and takes feedback very seriously. They also have engagement pulse surveys across IBM Design, and I have seen managers taking action to improve the culture. 

- IBM is very design-mature (aka design is valued even outside design teams). Everyone I have collaborated with at least understands the well-structured Enterprise Design Thinking methodology or concepts, and I don't have to waste my energy trying to advocate for the importance of design. I've felt that as a designer I'm equally important as offering management (basically product management) & developer teams. The last aspect of design maturity is that user research is valued; we have dedicated research teams and actually do usability testing & interviews to inform our designs. This is unique to mature design companies like IBM.

- Great starting place for fresh grads or anyone who just pivoted to the design industry. They have a great design bootcamp where you learn hands-on how to apply IBM's Enterprise Design Thinking to real IBM projects, and it helps you get on the same baseline footing when starting out. There's a lot of good investment in ensuring new designers feel supported when first joining IBM.

- Free snacks in the Austin studio (better than none!) back when we were still going to the office.

- Access to anyone at IBM that you want to talk to! For example, if you want to chat with people who are experts in future-facing things like blockchain, AI/Watson, etc, VR/AR, quantum computing.... these experts are unique to IBM. Nobody's stopping you from talking to these people to learn more, and it helps that we have Slack to facilitate quicker communication.

- I'm not as involved in this stuff, but diversity & inclusion seems decent, though they are reluctant to release numbers. The good thing is that IBM Design is actively working on ways to improve these things; there is a diversity & inclusion committee and regular panel talks to address issues and encourage a more diverse IBM.
cons:
- No annual salary increases to adjust for inflation, which is a little ridiculous. Most companies - especially tech companies - do this. Starting salary is ok but since there's no increases, you're basically losing your worth as you gain more experience each year unless you get promoted.

- This is a relatively no frills company, even if you are in the Austin design studio. If you really value perks like fancy high rise offices, free lunch, super high salaries / bonuses / stock buybacks / etc. like Google, Amazon, Microsoft, etc., I'm not sure IBM is going to work for you. Unfortunately this is the tradeoff for a truly great culture, I guess. (I have heard less good things about the culture at those competitors with their fancy perks though.)

- Perf is weird, it's officially once a year but you can discuss at any time. Not a con per say, but it's 100% up to you though to drive these discussions and advocate for yourself with your manager (likely not unique to IBM though).

- Some time zone differences. For my particular team, many of the developers I work with are in China. We just meet once every 2 weeks, but this also makes collaboration and communication a bit harder. On the other hand it's kind of cool to work with people across the world. I also work with developers across the US in CA & NC. Not all teams are this distributed though.

pros: The IBM culture is one of inclusiveness and value. It's refreshing to find a company that truly values it's employees. The teamwork is collaborative and fun. Training is plentiful and learning is continuous. The core values of bring your best self to work and be who you are create a positive environment.
cons: Often the hours are long. Since it's a large company getting things done is very bureaucratic , lot's of layers.

job_title: IT Senior Project Manager in Raleigh, NC
pros:
Working remote is embraced and for the most part, embeded in the culture. 

Excellent 401k plan.
cons:
Bureaucratic! It's extremely hard to get things done efficiently in this company. Escalations are the norm vs. the exception. 

At the end of the day, you're just a replaceable "resource". Pay raises are few and far between...and no where near the pace of inflation. Profit sharing is a joke. In my division, I would only receive profit sharing when the entire division did well - regardless if the specific projects I managed and controlled were profitable and successful. It was very rare that the entire division did well, and when they did, the amount of the profit shared was minuscule. Somehow, the CEO and top brass always seemed to get their bonuses. 

The talent pool has been depleted in the ever going chase to reduce cost.

pros: Great opportunity to travel the globe and interact with other IBMers and clients.

You are a number at IBM and it is humiliating.

review_title: IBM GSDC Poland Wrocław (CIC Wrocław & Katowice) a great place to work with great group of people
pros:
1. Extremely dedicated HR team, in my 10+ years of work experience working with various multinational companies, I have never seen a more dedicated and friendly HR team as I came to know one exists in IBM CIC Wrocław. They were always available for assistance throughout the year long process and through very difficult times of COVID crisis. (really exceptional job).
2. Amazing team of technical staff, (this obviously depends on the team that a person joins in to), as far as I can say my team was very welcoming and extremely supportive. They provided all possible help to me and brought me up to speed on anything that was required to work and provide great delivery to the customer.
3. Great manager (this is again going to vary from person to person) but as far as my manager is concerned, he is the most level minded person and an exceptional character, he literally makes all possible efforts to make the team work to the best of their abilities, I have never come across a manager with such exceptional capabilities. He a real gem in this IT world where you can really have terrifying experiences with your managers (which is more likely to happen).
4. An infinite learning opportunity. Literally the biggest benefit of working at IBM is the immensely massive source of learning. And now thanks to IBM's partnership with udemy the massively large source has become even more mega.
5. Work life balance, for all those people who are looking for balancing their work and personal life. It is really a great place that affords you all that liberty.
cons:
1. Uncertainty of company structure due to new announcement of "NewCo" spin off.
2. Lots of possible lay-offs and cost cutting (this is not new IBM has always found ways to do that).
3. Bureaucratic management structure , takes time to process anything , hence things move slowly which can be frustrating at times. (But hopefully that may change if one thing is to improve with "NewCo" spin off)
4. Salaries are not competitive compared to rest of the market players, (IBMers are never happy with their salary compensation and hikes but that has always been the fact historically, people work here not for the money , but for the joy of the technology and for the learning and growth).

pros: Generally, the people at IBM are all amazing. It is extremely rare to find anyone rude or arrogant. There are a lot of people that care within IBM, and there is a real sense of community.
cons:
*Disclaimer: I am a UK based employee.

There are a lot of little things that make me personally feel like more of a number rather than a person. The lack of employee appreciation, the disconnect between upper management and the rest of employees, no free tea or coffee (UK Based), the recent and savage redundancies which have left many feeling betrayed, the list could go on. Though some of these are minor things they have a big impact, especially when you look towards other companies, smaller companies, who are able to offer so much more to their staff.

Personally, I feel less and less valued, especially as someone within the technical community. Much of the praise given goes out to the Sellers or Consultants who bring in the big bucks not to technical professional who actually MAKE the solutions. This is furthered by a majority of Executives being from a consultancy background rather than technical, so as a "techie" in what was a "tech" company, there is a disconnect.

Career wise, you can progress. But it will take a lot of time and require you to have a number of specific "badges" to tick the boxes. Speaking from a technical standpoint. Your career pathway can be heavily influenced simply by what part of IBM you are in. Within the team I work in at the moment, our designer took much much longer to progress simply because our part of the business did not have a set guideline for what a designer requires in terms of experience/badges in order to progress.
If, as a techie you wanted to progress into senior roles, the majority of the time you would have to step away from being technical to consulting, as the levels of seniority just aren't there.

review_title: A job that makes you believe in the impossible
pros: It feels like you're surrounded by endless opportunities at IBM. The crazy smart people, the best-in-class methodologies, the countless trainings available, access to literally all industries and biggest clients...
